For there was no yeare, wherein they two were Consulls, as by the Fasti, both Greeke, and Latine is euident. Baronius heere takes vpon him to play the Criticke, and tellsEr • ore librariorum contingere potuit, vt loco Licinij, Constantini nomen sit positū. Bar. ibid▪ vs that Constantines name is inserted
in stead of Licinius; and so this Councell, and the disputation therein, should happen in the Consulship of Licinius the fift time, and Crispus, which is the thirteenth yeare of Constantine. But so vnhappy is the Cardinall in this his Criticisme, that himselfe expresly refutes the same. For speaking of the tenth yeare of Constantine, wherein Constantinus Augustus, and with him Licinius were both of them Consulls the fourth time, he saithBar. an. 315. nu. 10., Hoc ipso anno▪ in this very tenth yeare of Constantine, and in this Consulship was held that famous disputation at Rome, betwixt Pope Siluester and the Iewes. And this hee saith, is testified by the Exordium of the Actes of Siluester set downe in the Vaticane Copies, and in two other ancient Manuscripts, the one of St. Mary the greater, the other of his owne Library. Binius further addesConstantino & Licinio 4. Consulatum agentibus, qui est Christi 315. & Siluestri • . & Constantini 10. hunc conuentum celebratū fuisse Acta Siluestri, & lex 1. de Iudaeis, Cod. Theod. testā tur. Bin. not. in Conc. Rom. 1. §. Sub., that not onely the Acts of Siluester, but (which is a most shamelesse vntruth) the very Imperiall law made in that tenth yeare against the Iewes doth testifie the same. So infatuated was the Cardinall in this cause, that what hee writes in one yeare, not onely Binius, but himselfe also confutes in another.

But let vs see, if this his second correction, approued by Binius, and confirmed by so many ancient copies, and by the Imperiall law, will saue the credit of these Actes of Siluester. Truely this note of time doth vndeniably demonstrate those Acts to be altogether false and fabulous. For it hence cleerely followeth, that Constantine was not onely conuerted to the Christian faith, but sought also to conuert others in the tenth yeare of his Empire. Now the Acts of Siluester, and Pope Hadrian, confirming them
as authenticall Acta Siluestri ab ••• driano velut authentica c •• ata fuerunt. Bin. Not. in Conc. Rom. 1. §. Concilium., tells vs, that Cū ad fidem conuerteretur pius lmp. Constantinus. Had. Epist. 1. Constantine was not conuerted till hee fell into his leprosie, and vntill Peter and Paul appeared to him in a dreame, at which time he was so wholly ignorant of Christianity, that hee knew not whether Peter and Paul were gods or no. Constantine fell not into his leprosie as Binius assuresBin. Not. in vitam Silu. §. Siluester. vs, till hee had murdered his sonne Crispus: and that was in the ninteenthVt liquet ex Bar. an. 324. nu. 1. vbi ait Hic plane ānus demonstratur esse, quo dicuntur esse necati. & Binius ait Crispū occisum, an 324. Not. in Conc. Rom. 2. §. Cō stantino. yeare of Constantine. Seeing then Constantine by the Acts of Siluester, was conuerted to the faith, and become an earnest maintainer of Christianitie, one who assembled a Romane Councell of purpose for maintaining the same, in his tenth yeare, when hee and Licinius were the fourth time Consulls, it certainely followeth, that all, which those Vaticane Actes of Siluester, approoued by Pope Had • ian, report of Constantines persecuting the Church, of his leprosie, of his baptisme by Siluester, that all these are false and fabulous lies, yea and that the very selfe same Actes of Siluester (wherein they were first of all deuised and forged) doe vndeniably conuince them to be such.

After the time, let vs consider the occasion of this Romane Councell, and that famous disputation of Pope Siluester therein. Helena Acta Silu. apud Bar. an. 315. nu. 11▪
being in the East with two of her nephwes or grand-children, Constantine, and Constantius, being then Emperours, she as yet being a Gentile Helen • gentilis adhuc, à Iudae • s pene Iudaea eff • cta. ibid., was almost turned to Iudaisme, and • earing that her sonne Constantine was conuerted to Christianitie, and baptized, Haec vbi Helena in Bithinia cosistens audiuit. Iac. Voragin Legen. Siluestri. & idē Nicepho •• s t • adit. lib. 7 ca. 36. & Antonin. part. 2. hist. c. 1. sh • e was offended
therewith, and thereupon Co • mo • in 〈◊〉 , infenso animo ad e • m sc • ipsir. Act. Silu. apud Bar. loc. cit. du • è 〈◊〉 . Vorag▪ & Anton. locis ci •
▪
writ very angerly vnto him, vttering in her letter many blasphemies Multa blasph • mans in •• ristum. Act. Silu. loc. cit. against Christ; perswading Ipsum ad Iudaeor • religionē amplect • ndum 〈◊〉 . Act • Silu. apud Baron. & Antoninū loc▪ cit▪
Constantine to embrace the Iewish religion. Constantine thereupon writ backe to his mother, and told her that hee would haue a publike Ibid. disputation at Rome, Vt vtranam religio praestantior foret, disputatione probaretur, To try whether the Christian or Iewish religion were truer, willing Vorag. & Anton. loc. cit. her to bring the best learned of the Iewes to plead for their part. Whereupon there Qui coram ipsorum p • trona Helena dissererēt. Act. Sil. apud Bar. loc. cit. came 120.Nicep. loc. cit. learned Iewes, sent from Isach the high Priest, with Helena their Patrone, and disputed against 24. Romane Bishops: In that disputation, Pope Siluester ouercame Hadr. Epist. 1. ca. 53. the Iewes, by the iudgement of those two heathen men Crato Victores effecti sunt a bi
• rio Cratonis philosophi, & Zenophil • , quos ad id eleger • nt. Bin. ex Act. Silu. in Not. ad Conc. Rom. • . De communi consensu duos Iudices gentiles statuerunt. An • ō. loc. cit. and Zenophilus, who were by the common consent of both sides made iudges of that disputation, whereupon Helena (with many others) prostrating Helena nondū instituta, • rudiri se & baptizari flagitat. Zonar. to. • . psal. • 3. H • lena patriae religionis cultu relicto, ad Siluestri procidit p • d • s, ab • odēqu • , fid • i mysteria edoct • . Nicep. loc. cit. Tūc regina, Iudaei, Iudices, & caeteri omnes cōuersi 〈◊〉 ad. fidē ▪
• ac Vor. & Antonm. locis. cit. her selfe as Siluesters feet, was at that time conuerted and baptized. This is the summe and effect of that Romane Councell, as it is set downe in the Actes of Siluester, and of those who tooke it from those Actes, namely Pope Hadrian, Zonaras, as Nicephorus, Cedrenus, Antoninus, the Arch-bishop of Genoa, Baronius and Binius. In which legendarie fable, there are not so many words as lies.

1. That this Romane Councell followed the baptisme of Constantine, is palpably vntrue. For as Baronius Bar. an. • 15. nu. 10. and Binius Bin. not▪ in hoc. C • nc. haue assured vs, it was held in the tenth yeare of Constantine, whereas by
their owne account Constantine was not baptized till the ninteenth, but by the true account, not till the one and thirtieth, or last yeare of his Empire. Now that those Actes of Siluester doe put this Councell after the baptisme of Constantine, Baronius doth testifie, who for this ver • e cause saithBar. an. 324. nu. 97., Praeter ordinem temporis ea hic inserta, These things touching the first Romane Councell, are heere inserted in the Actes of Siluester, but against the order of time. For that Councell, saith heeBar. an. 315. nu. 10., was held in the tenth yeare of Constantine, that is, nine yeares before hee was baptized.

2. Those Vaticane Actes affirme, the two sonnes of Constantine, namely Constantinus and Constans to haue beene Augusti, that is, Emperours, before the tenth yeare of Constantine, when this Councell is supposed to haue beene helde. An vntruth so notorious that Baronius Ibid. nu. 13. calls it, deforme mendacium, an vgly lye.

3. That Helena heard of Constantines baptisme as by those Actes shee must, seeing hee was baptized shortly after his conuersion) and as Nicephorus sup. loc. cit., Antoninus, and the Arch-bishop of Genoa say she did, is an euident vntruth. Constantine, as we haue formerly prooued, was not baptized till his last yeare, and a little before his death; and Helena died diuers yeares before that time, as both Eusebius Eus. lib. 3. de vit. Conc. c 45, and Socrates Soc. lib. 1. ca. 13. vbi morte Helenae declarata, subijcit. ca. 14. postea Imperator, &c. shew, and Baronius Bar. ponit Helenae obitū an. 326 (eo. a • . nu. • 9.) id est 5. ann • s ante obi • um Constantini. confesseth.

4. Those Vaticane Acts affirme, that Constantine was conuerted to Christianitie before his mother
Helena, and that shee was a Pagane, a Iudaizing Pagane, not conuerted to the faith till the time of this Councell, when her sonne was a maintainer of the faith. Of which, heare the censure of their owne men. It is vntrue, saith Binius Bin. not. in Conc. Rom. 1. §. Concilium., that Constantine was a Christian before Helena. This is perspicuously demonstrated, saith Baronius Bar▪ an. 315. nu 12., to bee contrary to the truth, that Helena was made a Christian after Constantine, & he giues a reason out of Paulinus worthy obseruing▪ that Helena did instruct and traine vp Constantine in pietie, euen à puero, from his very child-hood: whereby you may further see what truth there is in those Actes of Siluester, in the Edict of the Donation, and in Pope Hadrian who approouedBin. loc. nu. per cit. those Actes as authenticall, seeing those ActsAct. Silu. apud Hadrianū Epist. 1. and the EdictEdict. Cōst. apud Bin. pa. 296. b. make Constantine so ignorant of Christianitie in the nineteenth yeare of his Empire, when hee was more then fortie yeareVixit annos 65. regnauit 31. Socr. lib. 1. ca 26. old, that hee then knew not whether Peter and Paul were gods, and whether Christians held them for gods or no.

Now because all the rest of the narration, as well the Romane Councell, as the disputation therein, and all the consequents thereof, doe all depend on this vntruth, that Helena was at that time a Pagane, inclining to Iudaisme, & vnconuerted, seeing this which is the foundation is a lie, (so Binius Mendacijs scatent Acta. Nam, &c. Bin. not. in id Cōc. calls it) all the rest must needes bee acknowledged for fables and lies. I will onely point at some of them.

5. It is vntrue that Helena was displeased with Constantine for imbracing the faith, as the Vaticane Acts of Syluester, sayAct. Silu. supra cit. she was, 6. That she writ vnto
him in angry manner for that cause, as the Vaticane Acts, Antoninus, and the lying Legend saySupra. shee did. 7. That she vttered many blasphemies against Christ in her letter, as the Vaticane Acts say she did. 8. That she perswaded Constantine to embrace Iudaisme, as the sam • Vaticane Acts affirme she did. 9. That Constantine for this end, decreed Constantinus statuit cō uentum, &c. Act. Siluest. supra. to hold a Councell, and haue a disputation at Rome, as those Acts, Zonaras Zona. tom. 3. • s d • creuit, &c. and Antoninus Anton. loc. cit. say he did. 10. That Issachar, or Isaac, was high Priest at this time, as the same ActsAct. Silu sup. say he was; It is exploratissimum, saith Baronius Bar. an. 315 nu 13., most certaine that there were no high Priests among the Iewes at this time, nor since the sacking of Ierusalem by Titus. 11. That Helena brought either 120. as Nicephorus Nic. supra., or 140. learned Iewes, as Antoninus, & the Archbishop
• ac. Vorag. in Leg. Silu. say she did, to dispute at Rome. 12. That there was twenty foure Romane Bishops to dispute on Syluesters side, as Nicephorus Ibid. saith there was. 13. That there was a Councell celebrated at Rome, or any assembly of those disputers, as the Vaticane Acts Act. Sil. sup., Pope Hadrian In quo Concilio. Had. loc. cit., Nicephorus In conuentu & colloquio. Nic. loc. cit., and after them Binius Binius vocat Concilium Romanum 1▪ sub Siluestro. affirme there was. 14. That there was had in that Councell, celeberrima disputatio, as Baronius Bar. an. 315. nu. 10. celebris disputatio. and Binius Bin. loc. cit. call it, a most famous disputation, is a most famous lye; though Pope Hadrian Had. loc. cit. approue it for an authenticke Hadrianus acta Siluestri velut authentica citauit▪ Bin. loc. cit. truth. 15. That Crato, and Zenophilus were Iudges of that disputation, as out of the Acts of Syluester Binius Bin. loc. cit. obserueth; and Antoninus with the Legendarian Arch-bishopAntonin. & Iac. Vor. loc. cit▪ sets downe the very words, arguments, and answeres vsed i • that disputation. Fit Iudges I wisle, heathen men to iudge of Christianitie; and iudge, whether it or
Iudaisme were the true Religion; and iudge also of the infallible iudges doctrine, whether it were truth or heresie. 16 That Siluester was president in this Councell, as Pope Hadrian saithHad. loc. cit. he was. 17. That Siluester ouercame the Iewes not onely by reason, but by miracles also, as the same Pope Hadrian Had. Zonar. Nic. & Iac. Vor. locis ci • ., Zonaras, Nicephorus, Antoninus, and the Archbishop of Genoa affirme. 18. That Zambres the Iewish Magitian, wrought a miracle to confirme Iudaisme; and that was, to kill a most fierce Bull drawne thither by an 100. men, onely by whispering a word in the Buls eare, as Zonaras Zon. Anton. & Iac. Vor. l • c. cit., Antoninus, and the Archbishop say he did. 19. That when Zambres could not restore the dead Bull to life, Siluester did it by a word, saying, Surge • aure, rise vp dead Bull, and stand on thy feete, as Zonaras, Nicephorus, Glicas, Antoninus, and the Archbishop of Genoa affirmLoc. cit. he did; adding, that the dead Bull presently rose vp and went forth, cum omni mansuetudine, verie gently and mannerly. 20. That there was a Dragon
• adam Acta Siluestri habent de Dracone in specu morante & homines enecante. Bar an: 324 nu. 97. Cedr. Glic. ann. part. 4. pa. 345. then at Rome in a caue, which was 365. steps deepe, which killed euery day 300.Multos • aedebat. Cedr. & Glic. loc. cit. Anton. & Iac. Vorag. loc. cit. Quotidie 〈◊〉 6000. hominū flatu suo interficiebat. Mart. Polon. ad an. 314. men and more, with his breath, as Glicas, Cedrenus, Antoninus, the Archbishop, the Actes of Siluester, and Mart. Polonus doe affirme. 21. That the vestall virgins brought victuals to this Dragon the first day of euery moneth, as the Vaticane ActsDici • ur (in actis Siluestri) Kalendis sing • lis eidem Draconi à vestalibus virginibus suppeditari solita alimenta. Bar. ann. 324. nu. 98. say they did; but Baronius addes, in nulla parte consistit, this is in no sort coherent. 22. That Siluester after the disputation, further to confirme the truth of Christianitie, and confound the Iewes, went downe into the caue, and there bound the Dragons mouth with a thred, and sealing vp the brazen gates wherin the
Dragon was, with the signe of the Crosse, commanded the Dragon to stay there till the comming of Christ, as Antoninus Antonin. & Iac. Vor. loc. cit., the Archbishop of Genoa, Mart. Polonus Draconem aeneis po • tis conclusit & vsque ad diem iudicij ser • s ob fi • mauit. Mar. P • l. ad an. 314, and the Acts ofEx Actis Siluestri citat: • oc Bar. ann. 324. • u. 97. Siluester affirme he did: which for this very cause are reproued by Baronius in this manner: Nothing Nih • l fabulosius • ffingi posse certum est, &c. Bar. ib. nu. 98. is more fabulous, then that which is affirmed in the Actes of Siluester, that the Dragon should remaine immortall till the comming of Christ. Thus Baronius, who yet saithBar. ibid. nu. 97., rem gestam veram credimus, We belieue (they had need of a very strong faith) that this thing touching the Dragon was truly done; and the picture Ibid. nu. 102 of Siluester set vp in Churches with a Dragon bound at his feet, is a Trophe or Monument of that victorie of Siluester; and veritatem Historiae repr • sentat, represents the truth of the Historie: • e might better haue said, it represents the fiction, and • he notable lie of that fable. 23. That Helena Helenam tū pr • mum conuersā f •• sse a •• Nice. loc. cit. & Zona. to. 3. • o. 83. Mart. Pol. loc. cit. Tunc Regina, Iudaei, Iudices & caeteri omnes ad • idem conuersi • unt, Anton▪ & Iac. Vor. loc. cit., the two I • dges, & caeteri omnes, and all the rest of the Iowes were then (vpon those miracles of the Bull, and the Dragon) cōuerted to the faith of Christ, as Niceph Zonaras, Mart. Polonus, Antoninus, and the Archb. of Genoa say; and Christianitie was by these miracles enlarged, as saithDil • tantes Christianorum • idem, tam per sc •• ptu • am, quàm per miracula. Hadr. loc. cit. Adrian •
24. That the Empresse Helena being not before instructed in Christian Religion, was now first Zon. & Nic. loc. cit▪
informed therein, and then baptized, as Zonaras, and Nicephorus say. By all these, (besides a number moe) which are so many latchets depending on that grand lye, that Helena was not conuerted to the faith before Constantine, or before the 10. yeare of his Empire, it doth now clearely appeare, that the first Roman Councell vnder Syluester, is a meere fiction,
and Chymera, and that those Acts of Syluester, which they so often Bar. an 315 nu. 10. & ann. 324. nu. 31. 33 40. 41. & saepe alibi. Bin. Not. in vitam Siluestri. §. Siluester. & §. De suscepto. & §. Quē. & Not. in Conc. Rom. 1. & No • . in Edict. Constan §. Ipse. Steuch. pa. 87. vbi ait historiam Siluestri, ab vniu •• so Niceno Concilio 2. approbatam. & praecipuè pag. 44. Marta. ca. 30. nu. 8., and with so great ostentation vrge in many causes, are nothing else but a verie puddle and sinke of lies. Besides these, there are other false and fabulous narrations in those Acts of Syluester, as that SiluesterHaec in Ac
• i • Siluestri haberi testatur Bin. Not. in Conc. Rom. 1. & Baro. ann. 315. nu. 16. abrogated the faest on Saturday, of which Binius saith, it is a lie; that Siluester was ordained by Melchiades, of which Binius againe saith, it is a lye; that he instituted, that the first day in the weeke should be called the Lords day: of which Baronius saithBar. loc. cit., it is portentosum mendacium, a monstrous lie, and many such like: for those Acts of Siluester scatent Vt ait Bin. loco cit. mendacijs, do flow and abound with lies: but I will onely in the last place touch one other point, which much concernes the honour both of Constantine and his most religious parents.

The Acts of Siluester either following or deuising a lying fable, say, that Helena Referunt Acta Siluestri Helenam ex Bythinia ori
• idam fuisse, 〈◊〉 Bin. Not. • n Conc. 1. Rom. sub Silu. was borne in Bythinia. The fable touched by Zosimus Zosim. lib. 2. vbi ait Constantinum natum ex muliere quae mater familias non esset, nec legit • me Constantio conuenit. pa. 23., but at large set downe by Nicephorus Nic▪ lib. 7. cap. 18., is this: When Constantius Clorus was sent in an Ambassage to Persia, being at Drepanum a towne in Bythinia, incensed there with lust, he tooke Helena his hosts daughter for his Concubine, and of her at that time begat Constantine, & then returning home was made Caesar. A meere fiction; deuised by the maligners of Christianity of purpose to disgrace the honour of Constantine, as if he had been base of birth; and the pietie of Constantius his father, and his mother Helena, whom further in scorne and contumely they called stabulariam, an Inne-keeper.
That this whole narration is vntrue, there is an euident proofe taken from the time; seeing Constantius is said to haue beene made Caesar when he returned either the same or the next yeare out of Persia. For it is certaine by Eusebius Constantius 16 imperij annodiem obijt. Eus. in Chron. an. 311., that Constantius reigned in all but sixteene yeares, the three last of which, he was Augustus or Emperour, and all the former but Caesar. The same is cleare by the Fasti of Onuphrius, whereConstantius imperauit Caesaris nomine annos 13. mē ses 5. Onuph. in Fast. an. vrb. 1053. Constantius is said to haue bene made Caesar in the Consulship of Tiberianus the second time and Dio; from whose Consulship, to the death of Constantius, are directly sixteene yeares. Cuspinian Cuspinian. 14. annos tribuit in Fast. ann. Christi 294. & seq. giues one, Epiphanius, and the Greeke Fasti two yeares lesseEpiph. lib. de Pond. & mensur. pa. 417. tribuit Constantio tantum 13. annos. Fasti Graeci solum 12. ei dant. pa. 283. to the reigne of Constantius; but I am content to allow the most. Now if this fabulous narration of Nicephorus were true, Constantine being borne within a yeare or two of his fathers being Caesar, and succeeding immediatly in the Empire vnto his father, could not possibly be aboue seuenteene, at the most not aboue twentie yeares, when he began to be Emperor. Whereas it is most cleare and certain, by Eusebius Eus. lib. 4. de vit. Const. cap. 53., Socrates Annū 65. ingressus, obijt Soc. lib. 1. ca. 26. & annos 31 regnauit. ibid., and others, that he was 31. yeares old at that time.

Besides, that Helena was not of Bythinia, nor Constantine borne there, it is certaine and vndeniably proued by the Panegyrist, (Eumenus as it is thought) who in his Panegyricke made at the verie solemnitie of Constantines marriage with Fausta, in the presence of Constantine himselfe, and all the Nobles, said thus vnto him; Thy Paneg. Maximino & Constantino Paneg. 9. ca. 3. father Constantius did deliuer Brittanie from bondage, tueas nobiles illic oriund • fecisti, thou by being borne there, and descending of the Brittish
blood, hast made that countrey noble. The same is testified by Pomponius Laetus Pom. Laet. in Constantio Clo • o & Galerio., Constantinus natus est in Britannijs, Constantine was borne in Britaine, of Constantius and Helena: by Henric. Huntingtoniensis Hen. H • nt. hist. lib 1., Constantine was a Brittaine, Genere, & Patria, both by his descent, and by his Countrey: by Onuphrius Onuph. lib. de Rom. princip. pa. 73., Constantine, natus est in Brittannia, was borne in Brittaine. A truth so cleere, that Cardinal Baronius; no well-willer to the honour of this Iland, could not but with strong asseueration acknowledge the same; apertissime Bar. an. 306. nu. 16. constat Constantinum in Britannia ortum, it is most cleare and manifest, that Constantine was borne in Brittanie; againeIbid., certum est, it is certaine, that Helena did bring forth Constantine in Brittanie: and againeBar. Notis in Martyrol. Rom. August. 18., I haue proued elsewhere, quòd Helena Brittanna fuerit; that Helena was a Brittish woman. The very same doth Posseuine Posseu. Appar. in Niceph. acknowledge, confessing Helenam, Britannam fuisse, & Constantinum in Britannia peperisse, that both Helena was a Brittish woman, and that she brought forth Constantine in Brittanie. Yea he reprooues Nicephorus for saying the contrarie; which reproofe of P • sseuine is sufficient also to refute that very idle, and vntrue opinion of Iul. Firmicus Iul. Firmicus vixit tempore Constantini, vt ex ipsius scriptis liquet. the Astrologian, followed by Ioh. Leuinius, thatConstantinus apud That sum genitus. Iul. Firm. Mathematicus. lib. 1. (Leuin. falso citat. lib. 2) Mathes • s. ca. 4. Constantine was borne at Tharsus. Certainely his Horoscope did much deceiue him; placing Constantine not onely in another House, but in another Region and Climate alalso. Whose errour Leuinius might easily haue discerned, seeing Firmicus affirmesIbid. further, That Constantine, à primo aetatis gradu Imperij gubernacula retinuit, held the gouernment of the Empire, euen
from his first age. For Socrates Vixit 65. regnauit 31. annis. Socrat. lib. 1. c • . 26., and others do truly and certainly teach, Constantine not to haue beene Emperour, till after the thirtie one yeare of his age. Nay the errour of Leuinius is vtterly vnexcusable, whoIoh. Leuin Not. ad Pan •
gyric. 5. ca. 4. together with that opinion of Firmicus, maintaines also the quite contrarie assertion of Nicephorus, that Constantine was borne at Drepanum, a Towne in Bythinia: which two assertions are each of them contrarie to the other, and both contrarie vnto the truth; the cleare and vndoubted testimonie of the Panegyrist, vttered before Constantine himselfe, in that nuptiall celebritie, giuing assurance, that he was borne neither at Tharsus nor Drepanum, but in Brittanie, and of Helena, a Brittish woman.

As for that other calumnie of Zosimus Zosim li. 2▪ , and manyOros▪ lib. 7. cap. 25. ex concubina Helena. Idem ait Niceph. loc▪ cit. Mar. Scot. an. 305. Her. Contr. ann. 305. Rheg. an. 244. Got. Viterb. an. 290 alijque. others, That Helena was not the Wife, but the concubine of Constantius: it is clearely refuted by Eutropius, who saithEutr. lib. 9▪ in Dioclesiano, that when Constantius and Galerius were made Caesars, and married, the later to Valeria, and Constantius to Theodora, the daughter in law to Maximianus the Emperour, ambo vxores quas habuerant repudiare compulsi, they were both compelled to put away their former Wiues. The like saith Aurelius Victor Au. Vict. in Diocles. pag. 152., Constantius and Galerius were ioyned in affinitie to Dioclesian, diremptis prioribus Coniugijs, their former marriages being dissolued. So also Pomponius Laetus Pom. Laet. in Diocles., they married new, being compelled, priores vxores repudiare, to forsake their first Wiues. The Arrians and Paganes, saith TheophanesTheophanis integer textus citatur Graece apud Aug. Steuch. lib. de Const. donat. pa. 159., doe slander Constantine to
haue bin a Bastard, but they lye: for he was borne of royall parentage, his father Constantius, being the Nephew of Claudius the Emperor, and of his first wife Helena he begat Constantine the Great. Constantine, saith Zouius Zou. eccle. hist. • d ann. 306. nu. 5., was borne of Constantius Clorus, and Helena, non quidem concubina, vt somniat Nicephorus, sed iusta vxore, who was the lawfull wife, and not the Concubine of Constantius, as Nicephorus dreameth. Helena the Empresse, saith Onuphrius Onuph. lib. de Rom. princip. pa. 70., was prima vxor Constantij, the first Wife of Constantius Clorus. Helena, faith Christ. Masseus Chr. Mass. an. 337., was the daughter of Coel, quae nupta Constantio, who being married to Constantius, bare him three sonnes. Constantius, saith Volaterranus Volat. lib. 3. Geograph., duxit in matrimonium Helenam, tooke to Wife Helena. The Emperours Dioclesian and Maximianus, saith Vitus Basinstochiensis Vit. Basinst. lib. 5. Hist. pa. 432., adopted Constantius Clorus, and Galerius, qui priores vxores repudiare coacti sunt, who were thereupon compelled to put away their former Wiues. And that the former Wife of Constantius was Helena, heIbid: also affirmes; adding, That Constantine Ibid. pa. 427 being borne (of her) in Brittanie, attained to that honour which the Druides had fore-told vnto him. Constantius Clorus, faith Zonaras Zonar. tom. 2. Annal. in Dioclesiano., declared that Constantine being his eldest sonne, ex priore coniuge susceptus, borne of his former Wife, should succeede to him in the Empire.

The testimonies of the Panegyrist, and Eusebius, both of them liuing in that age, is of more weight and authoritie then all the former, yea then any else who write of this matter. The former in the nuptiall celebritie of Constantine, saidEumen. Pa • eg. 5. ca. 4., Imperium nascendo meruisti, Thou, O Constantine, euen by
thy birth haddest right vnto the Empire, and wast theNeque • rat dubium quin ei competeret Haereditas. ibid ca 4. vndoubted heire thereof: whereas had hee beene base of birth, hee could haue had no right at all thereby, nor beene heire vnto it. Eusebius also speaking of the second marriages, of Galerius and Constantius Clorus, saithEuseb. in Chrō. an. 292., they both were compelled, vxores
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Ens. Chron. Graec. quas habuerant repudiare, to put away their former wiues; and the former wife of Constantius was no other but Helena, as is by all confessed. Whence it is certaine, not onely that Helena was truely the wife, and not the concubine of Constantius, (as Arians and Paganes did maliciously slander) but that in another place of Eusebius Latine ChronicleEus. Chron. lat. an. 309. in antiquis edit. sed an. 307. in edit. Lugd. cū. notis Iosep. Scalig., those words are corruptly, and both against the minde of Eusebius and the truth, inserted, that Constantine inuaded the Empire, ex concubina Helena procreatus, being borne of Helena the concubine of Constantius. For neither did he inuade, but most lawfully entred into the Empire, and that by a threefold title; First, by his birth Nascendo meruisti. Eumen. paneger. 9. ca. 3. & neque erat dubium quin ei competeret haereditas, ibi. ca. 4., being borne heire of the Empire: Secondly by the ioynt consent Vniuersus in te consensit exerci-tus. ibidem cap. 8. &, Iam tunc coelestibus suffragijs vocabaris. ib. ca. 7., and ioyfull, yea, celestiall suffrages and acclamation of the people: Thirdly, by the speciall designement manifeste sententia patris electus est Imperator. ibid. & apud Zon • loc. ante cit. of his pious father, appointing him to be his successour: all which the Panegyrist in plaine tearmes expresseth; yea, Zonaras Zonar. tom. 2. in Diocles. addes a further, and a fourth title, and that is, the designement of God himselfe, who by an holy Angell commanded Constantius to leaue the Empire to his sonne Constantine: neither was hee borne of a concubine, but as Eusebius Loc. nuper. cit. himselfe professeth,
of the lawfull wife of Constantius; Neither are those wordes extant in the Greeke Chronicle of Eusebius, and therefore, no doubt, both maliciously, and quite contrary to the minde and saying of Eusebius, inserted into the Latine. Vnto all which may bee added that most honourable testimony of Iustinian the Emperour: who speaking of the citie Helenopontus, saithAuthent. Tit. 7. Nou. Const. 28. ca. 1., that it was (o called by the most pious Emperour Constantine, in honour, honestissimae suae matris Helenae, & pientissimae mulieris, of his most honest mother Helena, a most holy woman; which Epithetes it seemes Iustinian of purpose giues, that euen by his Imperiall law, hee might wipe away that slanderous imputation which euen then was laid vpon her. For certainly, those titles of honestissimae, and pientissimae, had beene most vnfit, had either Helena beene vnhonest of body, or Constantine base of birth.

Now for that last scoffe of Stabularia, some learned men indeed, not so fully pondering this matter, haue affirmed it, to bee certaine, and that, ex sanctissimis Ecclesiae Patribus, by the testimonyes of most holy Fathers. But St. Ambrose (who is for ought I can finde, the onely Father that mentions this) is not a little mistaken by them. He thus writethAmbr. orat▪ de obitu Theodosij.: They say, she was at first stabularia. They say it, They indeede, who were Paganes or Heretickes, they who enuied Constantine, and scoffed at Christian religion, they said it. Iulian the Apostate, an enemy of Christ and Christianitie, was the first that said it, callingConstantinus imperitus ac stolidus. Iuliani verba in Act. 〈◊〉 j. citatis apud Ste • ch. p. 151 Constantine a foole, and Helena
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 . Iuliani verba. ibid. pa. 154. base and ignoble: they who were the disciples and
followers of Iulian, they said it. But Ambrose himselfe saith it not; hee onely shewes, in what a good and pious sence shee may bee so called. A good Inkeeper, who sought the manger of Christ so diligently; a good Inkeeper, who was not ignorant of that Hoste who healed the woundes of him that fell among theeues; a good In keeper, who esteemed her selfe but as dung, that shee might gaine Christ, and therefore Christ lifted her from the dung (according to their saying) to a kingdome. So Ambrose, not approouing what others said, but turning that which others said of her in derision, to such a sence as did best expresse her pietie. And whereas Eutropius Eutrop. lib. 10. in Constantio. calleth the marriage of Constantius Clorus with Helena, obscurius matrimonium, a more obscure marriage, his meaning is plaine. For hee neither meant, nor said, that it was simply ignoble, but speaking comparatiuely, and comparing it to his second marriage with Theodora the daughter in law to the Emperour; by which he obtained first to be Caesar, and then Emperour; in respect of the splendor of this second marriage, and the Imperiall dignitie obtained thereby, hee did and might well say, that the former was more obscure, or not so illustrious; though in it selfe it was both very honourable, and in no sort any disparagement to Constantius. For Helena was the daughter of Coel King of Brittany, as besides the vniforme consent of WritersAccepit filiā Regis (cui nomen erat Coel) Helenā. Henr. Hunting. hist. lib. 1. &, tradūt Annales Britannorū Helenā filiā fuisse Coel regis. • Cusp. lib. de Caesar. in Cō stantino. of the Brittish story, is declared by Nauclerus, an Historian both for diligence in searching the truth, and fidelitie in deliuering it, highly commended by Reucline Nostra historia (i. Naucleri) proba est ac fida. &c. Ioh. Reucl. in sua praefat. ad Naucl.; and
his testimony is well worthy obseruing. Hee purposely checking that saying touching Helenas meane parentage, which hee supposed Ambrose to vtter out of his owne, and not (as in truth • ee did) out of the opinion of other men, saithNaucl. gen. 11. an. 310., Helena the wife of Constantius was the daughter, regis Coeli, of Coel King of Brittaine, quamuis Ambrosius, though Ambrose call her stabulariam. And againeIdē. sub an. Chr. 177. gē. 6, Asclepiodotus King of Brittaine being slaine, Coel (who builded Colchester) succeeded vnto him; then Constantius who was (afterwards) Emperour, being sent into Brittaine, did quiet the whole Iland vnto the Romanes, and ducta Coelis filia Helena vxore, hauing married Helena the daughter of Coel, hee alone ruled in the Iland after the death of Coel. After him ruled his sonne Constantine the Great, by whose fauour, (for that both himselfe and his mother were Brittaines) the Kings of Brittaine, imperiali diademate vsi sunt, did vse an Imperiall Crowne. The like is affirmed by Genebrard; Constantine, saith heeGilb. Geneb. Chron. ad an. 315., Helenam Coeli, qui Britanniam occupauit, filiam vxorem habuit, tooke to wife Helena the daughter of Coel, who held the kingdome of Brittaine. This whole matter is at large related by Vitus Basinstochiensis: Carausius, saith heeVit. Basinst. lib. 5. Hist. pa. 433., perswaded the Brittaines to make him King, that so they might free the Iland from the subiection of the Romanes. The Romanes hearing thereof, sent C. Alectus to destroy that vsurper, and to reduce the Kingdome of Brittaine to the Romane dominion. Alectus hauing slaine Carausius, held the kingdome for three yeares; who being ouercome and slaine by Asclepiodotus, the Brittaines with one consent chose Asclepiodotus for
their King. When hee had gouerned a while, there fell out great enmitie betwixt him and Coel, then Duke of Colchester; who hauing killed Asclepiodotus, hee was made the King of Brittaine, by the name of Coel the 3. Then the Romanes to recouer the Iland, sent Constantius Clorus, a valiant aud wise man, who had a little before subdued Spaine. Coel vnderstanding both of his fame, and comming, entreated peace, and promised subiection, vpon condition that hee might haue the Kingdome, paying the yearely accustomed tribute to the Romanes. Constantius consented to him Constantio petenti nuptias Helenae, dat eam Coel in matrimonium ibid pa 435. ▪ & desired Helena his daughter, whom Coel gaue in marriage to him; and because shee was his onely childe and heire, with her hee left the kingdome of Brittaine to Constantius. The beautie Ibi. pa. 46 • . of this Helena was such that shee excelled all the women in the Prouince, nor was there any where, any comparable to her for skill in musicke and knowledge of the liberall Arts. So Constantius first, and after him Constantine the Great, held the Kingdome of Brittaine, together with the Romane Empire. So he▪

Let them now cease by malicious slanders to disgrace her whom both the Latine & Greeke Church highly honoured while shee liued, and hath enroulled her among the most blessed Saints Sanctae Helenae (celebratio) Aug. 18. Martyr. Rom. Graeci, in Menologio, habent commemorationem Constantini & Helenae, Maij 21., euer since shee departed. Let them also cease to disgrace Constantius, the father of Constantine, whose most worthy and deserued praises, are to all eternitie set forth both by the PanegyristEumen. paregyr. 5. ca. 3. & 4., and by Eusebius Eus. lib. 1▪ de vit. Constāt. ca. 9. 10. & 11.; he being so beautified with pietie, (besides other vertues) that Eusebius saithIbid. ca. 11., Omnem suam familiam vni Deo consecrauit, hee consecrated his whole family to the true God, putting away all Idolaters out of his
royall house, adding that most memorable reason, They Quomodo enim fidem erga Imperatorē seruare poterunt, qui aduersus Deum perfidi esse cō uincuntur. ibi. will neuer bee faithfull to the Emperour, who are perfidious vnto God: who also after his death, as the PanegyristEum. Paneg. 5. & 9. passi •• ., and Eutropius Eutr. lib. 10. in Constantio, say, was inter diuos relatus. And for a conclusion of this whole point, let vs heare that exclamation in the PanegyrickeEumen. Panegyr. 9. c. 9, O fortunata & omnibus beatior terris Britannia, O happy Brittainy, more blessed then any countrey, which first saw and saluted Constantine Emperour. I say more; which bred, and brought foorth both Constantine himselfe, and his most blessed mother, and had the first Christian Emperor, the renowned Constantine the Great, to bee the ruler, and Imperiall King of it. And thus much be spoken of those Acts of Siluester. Concerning which I do now intreat but a very reasonable request, which I hope will easily bee granted; that considering those Acts are cleerely demonstrated to be nothing else but a very sinke of lies; none would heereafter giue credite either to them, or to any who alleadge them as witnesses worthy of credite, in which number, first Pope Hadrian, then Albanus, Iacobatius, Steuchus, Marta, the Gregorian Glossators, Baronius and Binius are all to bee accounted.

Their next witnesse is Pope Gelasius with a Councell of 70. Bishops, Pope Gelasius, saith Marta Mar. loc. cit. nu. 26., beares witnesse to this Donation. Gelasius, sayAnnot in cap. Constantinus. dist. 96. the Gregorian Glossators, as also Anton. Ant. August. loc. cit. Augustinus, so speakes of the Actes of Siluester (wherein this Donation is expressed) vt videatur approbare, that hee seemes to approue them. Card. Albanus Alb. lib. cit. nu. 1., & after him Busaeus the Iesuite, puts out videtur, and saithBusaeus No
•• s in Epist. 3. H • nc mari. §. Papae Siluestro., The Acts of Siluester,
à Gelasio Papa approbati in Synodo, which are approued by Pope Gelasius in a Councel of 70 bishops, haue this Edict; and Steuchus Steuch. lib. cit. pa. 81. & pa. 44 Gelasius qui fatetur gesta Siluestri à plerisque legi & approbari, idem suo testimonio quae de donatione in ea historia scribuntur, comprobat. no lesse confidently writes, Gelasius approoues those things which are written in the Actes of Siluester, concerning Constantines Donation.

Truely, if Pope Gelasius doe (as these men auouch) approoue those Actes of Siluester, hee hath for euer blemished and disgraced the Pontifical Chaire, by approuing such false & fabulous narrations, as those Actes containe. But I trust, I shall free and fully acquite Gelasius, and that ancient Synod, from this their vile calumny and slander.

That Gelasius, with his Romane Councell did not approoue those Actes, their owne Bishop Canus doth cleerely testifie, when heeApud idoneos scriptores nusquam legi. Can. lib. 11. loc. Theolog. ca. 5. §. Quod deinde. saith that no graue or allowed witnesse among the ancient Writers, mention the leprosie of Constantine. Then certainely the author of those Actes of Siluester, in which that leprosie is set downe, is not an approued author: Likewise their owne Carerius witnessethAlex. Carer. lib. • . de potest. Rom. Pont. ca. 21. §. Accedit. the same, Compertum est, It is certaine, that nothing touching this Donation, is read in any approoued Historian: Then certainely, the author of those Actes, (seeing in him this Donation is read) is not approued, much lesse by so honourable approbation of Gelasius, with an whole Councell. Card. Cusanus at large declares the same: This Donation of Constantine, saith hee,Cusan. lib. 3 Concord. ca. 2. pa. • 81., in libris authenticis & in historijs approbatis non inuenitur, is not found in approued histories, nor any authenticall Bookes. Now seeing the Cardinall
knew that it was in the Textus ille, Constantinus, est ex Legēda S. Siluestri extractus ibid. pa. 781. Acts of Siluester, it is plaine, that hee iudged them not to bee approoued by by Gelasius. AgaineIbid pa. 782, neither doth the Councell, vnder Pope Martin, wherein those writings which were approued, are repeated, nec quisquam approbatus Author, nor any approued Authour, which I haue seene, make mention of th • se Acts of Siluester. Then doubtlesse the Author of those Acts was not approued by Gelasius. For certainly Cardinal Cusanus, and Bishop Canus Gelasius author gra • issimus Can. lib. ci • . cap. 6. §. Quod si. also held him with this Councell for an approued Author. The Cardinall yet addes; Let any, saith heCus. loc. cit. pa. 781., looke vpon the 15. dist. Cap. Sancta Romana, and what approbation Gelasius there giues to these Acts, & inueniet pauci roboris, and he shall finde it to be a verie cold approbation. For Gelasius saith, that though the Authour of those Acts be vnknowne, yet those Acts are read by Catholiques, and therefore they may be read. In which words, what manner of approbation there is, euery one, saith Cusanus, may consider. For if from hence any will conclude, that Gelasius approues those Acts, hee might as well conclude, because a prouinciall Synod at London did say, that many Catholikes in the Church of England, do read the Aurealegenda, that therefore the whole Synod and Church of England, do approue the Aurealegenda for a faithfull Historie. Textus non dicit Historiam veram, sed legiposse, saithCus. ibid. pa. 781. Cusanus, the Text of Gelasius, doth not say, that the Historie of those Acts is true, but that it may be read; and so also any fable may be read. Bishop Canus goes yet further: for though he sayCanus. lib. cit. cap. 5. §. Quod deinde., that Gelasius did not reiect those Acts, (to wit, not in expresse manner, as he doth the
Acts of George, of Iulitta, and many others) yet that in their generall censure of namelesse writings, the whole Synod reiected them, Canus clearely auoucheth, saying,Can. lib. 11. ca. 6. § Quod si., Gelasius with a Councell commands, that we Vt eas histori • s nullo modo amplectamur, &c. Ibid. should by no meanes, accept or credit those writings, which are published without the certaine name of the author; for such writings doe smell either of imposture, or heresie▪ Gelasius then, is so far from approuing (as they boast he did) those shamelesse Acts of Siluester, that by the confession of Bishop Canus, he did indeede prohibit and condemne the same.

And all this I haue said, supposing those Acts of Gelasius, which are now extant, and which are set downe in the 15. Dist. to be true and incorrupt. But there are sundry, and effectuall reasons to induce any man, that this, touching the Acts of Siluester, and much more in those Synodall Acts, is falsely ascribed to Gelasius and his Romane Councell. For in some ancient editions of that Romane Councell, This touching the Acts of Syluester is not set downe: as Baronius Bar. an. 324 nu. 31. vbi • atetur ea de Actis Siluestri, desiderari apud Gelasium in aliquo • odice. himselfe acknowledgeth. Yea but, saith heBar. ibid., they are in the collection of Cresconius, which is more ancient then others. If Baronius meane that which is called, Breuiarium Canonum Cresconij, or Concordia canonum, as it seemes he doth, (there being nothing else of Cresconius, which concernes Councels, mentioned in Posseuine Posseu. in Appar. in verbo Cresconius.) the Card▪ deludes his reader. For in all that Collection or Breuiarie, this touching the Acts of Siluester is no where mentioned. But say it were; is that Collectiō of Cresconius, think you, most ancient? No, there were many copies of the Acts of that Councell, long before Cresconius, who liuing
after Ferrandus (the SchollerFerrandus, qui Fulgentiū vti magistrum magno in honore habuit, claruit ann. 529. Posseu. in Ferrand. of Fulgentius) made not his collection, till about the yeare 540. some fiftie yearesNam Conc. Rom▪ sub Gelasiuo habitū est an. 494. after that Romane Councell was held. Baronius should haue said and prooued, (which hee neuer offers to doe) that in some authenticke Copies, this had beene extant. The Copies of any Councell, in lesse then fiftie yeares may easily be corrupted; especially if the corruption of them, may aduantage the Pope and the Romane See. Yea and this verie Councell to haue beene so corrupted, Binius acknowledgeth, sayingBin. Not. in. Conc. Rom. 1. sub Gelasio., It cannot be certain-knowen, Quae sit vera & pura lectio Gelasij, which is the true Text or reading of Gelasius. Againe, that in the best and most authenticke copies of that Romane Synod, this, touching the Acts of Siluester, was not extant, may bee perceiued by Gratian: for Card. Cusanus Non inuenitur in antiquis libris iste versus de historia Siluestri. Cusan. lib. & ca. cit. pa. 581. 582. witnesseth, That in the ancient Text of Gratian, there is set downe no more out of Gelasius, then vnto these words, (Item gesta Sanctorum Martyrum,) after which, is that concerning the Acts of Siluester. All that followes vnto the end of the decree, is added to the old Text of Gratian. And this not onely Cardinall Cusanus, but Guido surnamed Archidiaconus: yea the Gregorian Glossators doe testifie the same, who at these words, (Item gesta) thus writeAnnot. Gregor. in cap. Sancta Romana. distinct. 15., From hence vnto the end of the Chapter, omnia absunt à plerisque vetustis Gratiani codicibus, all is wanting in most of the ancient copies of Gratian, and this doth Archidiaconus also obserue. So they. Certainly, had Gratian found that which is now added, touching the censure of all those Apocryphall Bookes, in the true Acts of the Romane
Synod vnder Gelasius, he would not haue omitted it; for hee had not onely fit, but necessary occasion to expresse the same, as well as the former. Besides this, let any of iudgement compare the appobation giuen in that Synod to St. Augustine, St. Ierome, St. Basil, St. Athanasius, yea euen to the foure first generall Councells; with that which is giuen to Orosius, Sedulius, Iuuencus, and some others of farre meaner note: and hee will see it can no way beseeme the wisedome and grauitie of that ancient Councell. Of the former theyConc. Rom. 1. sub. Gelas. say onely, the Romane Church, non prohibet suscipi, forbids not the reading of them: of the latter they say, Wee Ibidem. praise Orosius, wee preferreIbidem. with great commendation Sedulius, we admireIbidem. Iuuencus: a proofe too too euident, that this vnequall censure proceeded not from so equall iudges. And as for Eusebius Caesariensis, their censure of him, is quite contradictory to it selfe: for in one place, they say, that for his singular knowledge of matters, they doe not Vsquequaque non dicimus renuendes. ibid. reiect the history and Chronicle of Eusebius: and a little after, they condemne the history of Eusebius Historia E •
sebij Apocrypha ibid. as apocryphall: adding, that the author Haec & omnia his similia, &c. cū suis authoribus, authorumque sequacibus, sub anathematis indissolubili vinculo, confitemur esse dā nata. ibid., and approouers of him, or any other of those apocryphall bookes, are for euer accursed by the Romane Church with an indissoluble band of an Anathema. Shall we thinke Gelasius and the holy Councell with him, to haue played the Satyres, and blow both heate and cold, commendation and condemnation of the selfe same writings, with one breath? Or may we not much more rightly conclude, that they (which I verily thinke to be true) neuer gaue this censure of
Eusebius? Which many not obseruing, think the Historie of Eusebius, the workes of Lactantius, of Clemens Alexandrinus, of Arnobius, of Victorinus, and diuers others there named, to haue beene condemned in that Councell. They onely set downe their Synodall iudgement, and approbation of those bookes mentioned in the former part of the Synodall Acts, which in the ancient copies of Gratian were onely expressed; and some other with a false hand, patched to the same Acts, the later part of them, which in the ancient copies both of Gratian, and (as Baronius confesseth) of some of the Synodall Acts themselues, were omitted. Howsoeuer, certaine it is, that if the Synodall Actes be corrupted (in such manner as I haue shewed and prooued) then Gelasius with that Romane Synod, approues not the Acts of Siluester: if they bee not corrupted, though in their particular mention of those Actes, they say, They A multis in vrbe Roma Catholicis legi cognouimus. Ibid. vbi nota, legi non publice in Ecclesijs Romae, sed priuatim, in vrbe. are read of many in the cittie of Rome, and may be read, (as is, & may be read the lying Legend also) yet in their generall censure of namelesse writings, they certainly condemne the same Actes, as being either forged, or hereticall; and whethersoeuer, of no worth or credit at all.

The next witnesse and last in this ranke, is Isiodorus Hispalensis. He, saith Marta Mart. ca. cit. nu. 26., beares witnesse to this Donation. Isiodorus praesul Hispalensis, saith Card. Iacobatius Iacob. loc. cit. nu. 30., Isiodore the Bishop of Hispalis, affirmes Constantine to haue made this Donation. Card. Albanus addesAlb. lib. cit. nu. • ., that Isiodore hath set downe the very forme of this Donation, inter gesta Concilij Niceni, among the
Acts of the Nicene Councell. In this testimonie, besides other, they shew three speciall frauds. First, they belye Isiodore Hispalensis. For he is so farre from bearing witnesse to this Donation, that he expresly teacheth, Constantine not to haue made the same. Constantine, saith heIsiod. Hispal. in Chron. an. mundi. 5535., In extremo vitae suae tempore, ab Eusebio Nicomediensi baptizatus est, was baptized of Eusebius Bishop of Nicomedia in the last part of his age, or a little before his death: whence it vndeniably followes, that he did not make this Donation, which as the Edict it selfeEdict. Const. loc. cit., the Acts of Siluester Act. Siluest. apud Bar. loc. cit. and Binius Bin. Not. in Edict. & in vit. Siluestri. assure vs, was made after Constātine was baptized by Siluester, and that was at least ten yeares before his death. Secondly, they pretend that Author, who cals himselfe Isiodore, and who made the collection of the Councels and Canons, to be Isodorus Hispalensis. An vntruth so euident, that this Author, in the PraefaceIsiod. praef. in tom. 1. Concil. which he praefixeth in suam Canonū collectionem, to his owne collection of those Canons and Decrees, makes mention of Pope Agatho and the sixth generall Councell: and therefore certainely liued after the time of that Councell, which was heldBin. in tit. illius Conc. & Bar. an. 681 an. 681. whereas Isiodore Hispalensis died 40. yeares before; to wit an▪ 636. as Baronius Bar. an. 636 nu. 7. and Bellarmine Bell. lib. de Eccles. scrip. in Isiodorus Hispal. doe witnesse. Their last fraud is in belying, and that most shamefully, euen this Collector also (whom they name Isiodore Hispalensis) as setting down this Edict among the Acts of that Nicen Councell. A palpable vntruth, as any may perceiue who looks but into the collection of the Councels by Isiodore. This Edict is entirely there set downe before he comes to the Canons, or any Acts of that Nicen Councell: So also in
Binius Bin. tom. 1. Conc. and others. Yea in the ancient collections of Isiodore, the Edict, and the booke de Primi • iua Ecclesia, was set (as the noteNot, ante lib. de primit. eccles. & Edictum Constā tini, tom. 1. Conc. in the Councels of Nicholinus his edition doth testifie, and Binius Bin. Not. in Epist. de primit. Eccl. §: Melchiadi. confesseth the same:) continenter post decreta Melchiadis: immediatly after the decrees of Pope Melchiades, and therfore before the life of Siluester, much more before the Nicen Councell which was held in Siluesters time, and is set after the life & epistles of Siluester. Thus in euery one of these 7. (which are their prime, principall & most ancient witnesses in this cause) you doe now clearly see the vile & detestable dealing of Marta, & the rest, who pleade for this Edict and Donation. Either they belye their witnesses, as they doe the 318. Nicen Fathers, and Isiodore Hispalensis; or else in stead of Fathers they obtrude most base, counterfait and forged writings, as in Eusebius, Hierom, Damasus the Acts of Siluester and Gelasius, we haue euidently demonstrated.

div.head: CHAP. XI.
The credit of foure Popes and two Councels, alledged for proofe of the Donation, examined: namely, Hadrian 1, Leo 9. Eugentus 3. the 2. Nicen, and the Councell at Constance.
div.p:
THE next witnesses alledged for this Donation, are foure of their Popes, whom all to beare witnesse to this Donation, they Mart. cap. 30. nu. 36. & 37. Steuch. pa. 89 Annot. Gregor. in ca. Constantinus. Ant. August. lib. 1. Dial. 6. pa▪ 53. boast, and we do willingly acknowledge. Before we particularly entreat of them, there are one, or two generall
answers to them all. First, how could any of these, know the truth and certainty of this Donation, seeing Hadrian was not Pope, till more then 440. Leo more then 720. Eugenius more then 800. and Nicholas more then 950. yeares, afterDonatio facta dicitur an. 324. nam co anno Constan. baptizatum asterunt. Bar. an. cod. nu. 41 & seq. Hadr. 1 coepit an▪ 772. Leo 9. ann. 1049. Eug. 3. an. 1145. Nichol 3. ann. 1277 Bin. in eorum vitis. Constantine is supposed to haue made this Donation? Can any man thinke such to be fit witnesses of a matter of fact, done so many hundred yeares before their times, vnlesse they haue some certaine euidence of former ages? And euidence they haue none, better nor more ancient, then the false, fabulous, and legendarie Acts of Syluester: to which if any will giue credite, he demonstrates himselfe to be altogether vnworthy of credit.

Again, of all men in the world the Popes are most vnfit to be witnesses in this cause. Did Marta neuer heare of that in the Digests, Nullus Dig. li. 22. tit. 5. l. 9. idoncus testis in resua intelligitur, none is thought a fit witnesse in his owne cause? that is, as theyCuius commodum & vtilitas ad se directo spectat. Venat. lib. • . tit. 20. do rightly expound it, when the profit redounds directly to him who is the witnesse. So it doth in this Donation, to the Popes: None do gaine so much thereby as they; nor is it a pedling matter, or a fly that such Eagles get thereby; the gaine of Rome, of Italy, of all the Westerne Prouinces, will haue a strong operation in such witnesses, as haue too well learned their lesson of Iulius Caesar, Si ius violandum, regni causa violandum est. The world is witnesse, that farre better Popes, of a better faith, and of more fidelitie then Hadrian, Leo, Eugenius, and Nicholas, haue for euer blemished the Roman See, for defending forgeries, euen then, when they looked but for motes and minnims,
in comparison of Rome, Italie, and the Westerne Prouinces. Of many examples I will instance but in one.

Pope Zozimus and Boniface 1. that they might by Appeales draw the gaine of some contentious businesses, to the Romane Court, pretended and pleaded Conc. Carth▪ 6. ca. 3. a Nicene Canon to haue decreed the same. That Canon, an wholeConc. Afr. ca. 101. & • 05 in Epist. ad Celestinum. Councell of African Bishops, by the authenticke copies of the Nicen Canons, conuinced to be a forgerie. And yet this is not the worst fault in those Popes. For (as Bellarmine Bell. lib. 2. de Rom. Pontif. ca. 25 §. Respo • demus & seq., Baronius Zozimus & Bonifacius citarunt canones Concilij Sardicensis nomine Nicenae Synodi. Bar. an. 4 • 7. nu. 99., and others tell vs) Pope Zozimus, and Boniface, when they named the Nicen, meant the Sardican Councell: in the 7. Canon of which, is verbatim set downe that very Canon, which Zozimus alledged, and the fourth Canon is also in effect the same. In both it is decreed, That it shall bee lawfull, out of other Prouinces, to appeale to the Bishop of Rome, and that hee shall haue power, to send if he will, Legates à latere, to end causes in Africke or other Countries.

Now this is a further demonstration, that the Popes for their owne gaine, feare not to vrge and vphold forgeries. For that these two Canons are forged, and were not extant among the true Sardicane Decrees, the same African Bishops (one of which was Saint Augustine) and their whole Councell doth euidently declare, sayingConc. Afric. ca. 105. in their Synodall Epistle to Pope Celestine; That any should bee sent from the side of your Holinesse, (to heare, and end causes in other Prouinces) in nulla inuenimus patrum Synodo constitutum, we finde it decreed
in no Synod. If in none, then for a certaintie it was not decreed either in the Nicene, or in the Sardicane, or in the first Constantinopolitane Councell; in which onely (vntill that time) were made such Decrees and Canons, as did binde the whole Church, of which kind of Decrees the Africane Bishops speake in that place.

Bellarmine Augustinus non agnoscit aliud Sardicense conciliū, quā haereticū. Bell: lib. 2 de Rom. Pont. ca. 25. §. Adde., Baronius Admirari nō desino quonam pacto accidisse po • uerit, vt verum Sardicense Cōcilium, Catholicos Africanae Ecclesiae praeteri • rit. Bar. an. 347: nu. 96. & 98., and Binius Bin notis in Sard. Conc. §. Approbatum. lidem Africani patres viden • ur▪ illud Sardicense Concilium planè ignorasse. Bin not. in Conc. Carthag. 6. §. Hoc • idem., would gladly perswade, that neither Augustine, nor those other Africane Bishops knew ought of that holy Sardicane Councel. A thing so incredible, that with reason none can imagine it. How could they be ignorant of a holy generall Councell? For that this Sardicane was such, though some learned men (from whose iudgement I craue leaue to dissent) haue thought the contrary, not onely Athanasius Athanas. Apol. 2. vocat Magnum Cōcilium. pa. 191. sic autem oecumeni cū vocat. vt eadē Apol. pa. 194. vocat Nicaenū Conciliū magnā Synodū, & alibi., Socrates Edicitur Conciliū generale. Soc. lib. 2. ca. 16., Sulpitius Seuerus Imperator iubet ex toto orbe apud Sardicā Episcopos congregari. Sul. Se • . lib. 2. sac. hist. §. His per., and Iustinian Vniuersale Concilium, expresse vocat Iustin. in Edicto contra tria Capitula. quod incipit, Scientes., but the Councell of Chalcedon Conc. Chalc. Act. 16. in Alloqu • t. ad Martianū. doth witnesse, wherein is mention of this Sardicane, as of a generall Councell, such as was that at Nice, at Constantinople, and Ephesus, among which this is reckoned. Yea the Actes of the Councell it selfe doe explaine the same. First, it is cleare, that there were assembled 344. BishopsIn vniuersum subscripserunt 344. ait Athan. Apol. 2 pa. 208., (farre more then were at Nice) and that out of 36. diuersRecensentur 36 Prouinciae ab Athan. Apol. 2. in principio & iterū in 2. Epistolis Concilij Sardicensis apud eundem Athan. Apol. 2▪ Prouinces, to wit, Egypt, Libia, Palestine, Arabia, Pannonia, Thessalia, Dacia, Misia, Thrace, Macedonia, Achaia, Crete, Spaine, France, Italy, Sicily, Sardinia, Africke, Brittania, and many more: yea there were
present in it, and subscribed to the Decrees thereof 36.Recensentur apud Athan. loco citato, pa. 207., Africane Bishops, one of which was Gratus Primate of Carthage; Againe, the Councell bindes the whole Sint vobis igitur Georgius &c. Anathema. sic omn • bus Episcopis totius Ecclesiae scribit Conc. Sard. in sine 2. Epist. apud Athan. loc. cit. Catholike Church to obserue their Decrees, which no other but a generall could doe. How could they possibly bee ignorant, I say not of this Synod, to which so many of their owne Bishops had subscribed, but of the Decrees also made therein? specially seeing they vsed to bring home a copie of the Decrees consented vpon in generall Councells, as themselues sayCōc. Carth. 6. ca. 9., that Cecilianus brought with him the Decrees made at Nice, at which hee was present.

Their first Councell at Carthage, is a certaine & vndeniable proofe that they knew right well this holy Sardican Councell; for therein Gratus, in the hearing of the whole Synod saidCōc. Carth. 1. habitū tempore Iulij. c. 5. thus, I remember that this was decreed, in sanctissimo Sardicensi Concilio, In the most holy Councel at Sardica: which first Councell at Carthage, to haue beene knowne vnto Augustine (to say nothing of the rest) none may doubt: nay it is Nefas, saith Baronius Bar. an. 347. nu. 97., to suspect Augustine to haue beene ignorant of the Ecclesiasticall Canons, considering hee by reason of his continuall conflicts with Heretickes, Omnia Concilia scripta euoluit & archiua reserauit, Tossed the Actes and Decrees of euery Councell, and searched all Registries: yea it seemes the Actes of this first Councell at Carthage, were (among diuers others) read in that their sixth Councell, wherein this cause of Appeales was moued by Faustinus the Popes Legate, seeing they sayCōc. Carth. 6. ca. 9., Let the copies of the Nicene Decrees, Et quae Patres
hic constituerunt, and those things which our fathers or predecessours haue heere (in Africke) set downe to confirme the same, bee inserted into these Actes.

Besides, none can doubt, but those learned Africane Bishops, especially St. Augustine, read and perused diligently the bookes of Athanasius. Now seeing in thoseApud Athā. Apol. 2., this holy Sardican Councell is described, and their very Synodall Epistle expressed, there is no doubt but St. Augustine both certainly knew, and willingly embraced the same, which hee saw was approoued by so many Bishops, and of so diuers Prouinces. Further, St. Augustine himselfe witnessethAug. lib. 3. contra Cresc▪ ca. 34., that hee read the Synodall Epis • le of the hereticall Councell at Sardica which was held by Arians: How could he then possibly, but know of the holy Sardican Councell held at the same time, by Hosius, Athanasius, and other Orthodoxall Bishops? of which the very Epistle of that hereticall Sardican Councell, makes often In suo conuenticulo habu • runt Osiū & Protogen • . & saepe similia Epist. Synodalis Conciliabuli Sardicensis▪ apud Hilar. lib. 2 in fragn • enti • . pa. 6. & seq & Bin. to 1. con. pa. 448. and expressem • ntion Or what thinke you, was become of the wit and iudgement of Binius, when hee saidPosteri in African • Ecclesia tempore Zosimi & Bonifacij vtrūque conciliū, Sardicēse, & Carthaginense 1. ignorauerunt. Bin. not. in conc. Sardic. §. canones. videntur plane ignoraste, Bin. not. in conc. carthag. 6. §▪ Hoc idem. Augustine was ignorant of this holy Sardican Councell? whereas himselfe confessethBin▪ Not. in conc: Sard §. O • cumen • cū., that Augustine in his 162. Epistle cals it, Plenarium vniuersae Ecclesiae concilium, A plenary Councell of the whole Church: and Baronius speaking of the Africane Bishops saithBar an. 347. nu. 97., it is satis compertum, cleere enough and certaine by the very publike monuments of the Africane Church, that the holy and lawfull Councel of Sardica, was known to the Catholike Africane Bishops.

Seeing then it is cleare and certaine, that St. Augustine and the Africane Bishops, who writ that
Synodall Epistle to Pope Celestine, knew both of that holy Sardican Councell, and of the true Decrees thereof, the memory whereofEodem forme saeculo celebratum Bar. an. eod. nu. 96. was but then fresh, that Councell being held not aboue eightie yearesCōc. Sardic. habitum an. 347. Bar. eo. an. nu. 1. Celestinus coepit an. 424. Bar. eo an before they writ this to Celestine: seeing, I say, they certainely knew all the Decrees thereof, and yet for a certaintie professe to Celestine, after so long and diligent search of that cause touching appealing to Rome, that no Synod had decreed, that the Pope vpon appeale might send his Legates to iudge and determine causes in other Prouinces; it remaines as vndoubtedly true, that (if no more) yet the Canon which Zozimus alleadged (which is now the seuenth) as also the fourth; wherein the authori • ie of receiuing appeales, and sending such Legates, is granted to the Pope, are not the true Canons of the holy Sardican Councell, nor were among the true Canons of that Councell, in the time of St. Augustine, and of those Africane Bishops. For had they truely beene there, they had as much furthered the Popes claime of receiuing Appeales, and sending his Legates; and they had as effectually procured the assent of the Africane Bishops thereunto, as if they had beene decreed by the great Nicene Councell it selfe: The Sardican being as generall as the Nice • e, and the authoritie of them both being equall, and the whole Church by the very Sardican Decree, being bound to obserue all the constitutions made by it. But Zozimus, Boniface, and Celestine, were concious to themselues, that those Canons (the fourth & seuenth) were no true Sardicane Canons, but meere impostures and forgeries, fathered on the Sardican
Councell, to lift vp the authoritie of the Romane See; and knowing further that if they had but once alleadged these, as Canons of the holy Sardican Councell, the Africane Bishops could, and would much more easily haue conuinced them of fraud & forgerie, then they did in alledging the Nicene Canons; those Popes, I say, knowing this, durst not in all those fiue yeares (so longQuinquennalem illā cō trouersiam Africanorū, vocat Bin. not. in Conc. Afric. pa. 646. the contention about this matter continued) so much as once whisper, or intimate to any, that the Canon falsly alleadged by Zozimus to bee a Nicene, was indeede a Sardican Canon.

And if any demand, whence this corruption of the Sardican Canons should proceed, the answer is very easie, by the old Cassian rule, Cui bono? Seeing the gainers by those forged Canons were the Popes, the forgerers of them must needes be either Popes, or their fauourers. And heereof that which Pope Hadrian the first affirmeth, giues a strong presumption, seeing the Sardican Canons (in such manner as they were in his time) were, as himselfe saithHadr. 1. in Epitome Canonum in Cōc. Sard., among the Romanes, but not among the Grecians; who yet no doubt, had all the true Decrees made at the Sardican Councell. Photius also Patriarch of Constantinople professethVt testatur Nich. 1. Epist. 6. §. post haec▪ of the Greeke Church, Non habere vel recipere, that they had not, or receiued not the Sardican Canons. Not meaning, as Baroniu •
Non reperiri apud se canones conc. Sardic. turpiter mentitus est Photius. Bar. an. 347. nu. 53. 54. ( • ailing against Photius) misconceiueth him, That they had not any copies at all of those Canons among them, for Photius him • elfe in his Nomocanon De ijs qui siūt episcopi ex L • icis, Syn. Sard. can. 10. Phot. in Nom. 〈◊〉 . 1 ca. 11. sed. in • anonibus Sa • d conc ab al • o • ibus vocatur 13. vt apud 〈…〉 pa. 437. expr • s •
mentioneth that very Canon, which Baronius vrgeth against him, and saith
〈…〉
, that Photius denieth that they
had it or the rest among them:) but hee meant they had them not in such esteeme, as the Romanes had: which to be Photius meaning, his owne words doe explaine, cited by Pope Nicholas Supra., non habere, vel recipere, they had them not in such manner, as to receiue them for Synodall authoritie, or for the true Canons of that Sardican Councell; In this sort, by reason of the fraud of the Latines, inserting false and fained Canons, they iustly receiued them not, nor approoued them; which Gratian well obseruing, and putting a difference betwixt the Greeke and the Latine Church, in their hauing of these Canons, saithDistinc. 16. ea. Quod dicitis. in rubrica, & cap. Ipso., The Sardican Councell (in regard of the Canons therof) Authoritate apostolica recipitur, Is receiued or approoued by the Popes authoritie; but it is not receiued among the Grecians. The Popes, or their fauorites, hauing for their owne gaine, forged (if not all) yet certainly diuers of those Canons, could doe no lesse then approue them; the Grecians knowing the forgery (if not of all) yet certainly of some of those Canons, and by name of that seuenth, (which Zozimus pretended for a Nicene Canon) could doe no lesse then reiect and condemne them.

It were easie by many other examples, to declare that the Popes haue made this a very trade and custome (as if it were a piece of Pope-craft) either thē selues to forge, or else (which is euery way as bad) to abett, countenance, & maintaine by their authority, such writings as were forged by others; and by them to build vp their owne pompe and pontificall glory. But leauing all the rest, I will now come to the examination of the credit of those foure Pope, who are
produced as witnesses for this Donation.

The first of them is Hadrian Mart. ca. 30. nu. 26. Steuch. pa 87. the first; who of all Popes that went before, is most shamelesse in vttering vntruths, and maintaining false and forged writings. I wil giue but a touch of either. For his vntruth, take that in his EpistleHadr. 1. Epist. 1▪ to the Emperors Constantine and Irene, which was readNic. 2. C • c. Act. 2. pa. 309. and appouedIbid. pa. 313. b. in their second Nicene Councel: where he shames not to say, That Churches were beautified with venerable Images, euen from the Apostles time vntill then, and hee further addes, that the Church, Sanctas eorum figuras veneratur, Did from that time worship the holy Images of the Apostles. A palpable vntruth, easie to bee refuted by Origen, who liuing within a hundred yeares of some of the Apostles, writ thus against Celsus: It is impossible Orig. lib. 7. cont. Cels. pa. 97. that one should know God, and make supplication to Images: and as for Christians hee addes, Nec simulachra quidem nos veneramur, We doe not adore Images: Of Lactantius, who liuing in Constantines time, saith, Non Lact lib. 2. ca. 19. est dubium quin religio nulla sit, vbi est Simulachrū, It is no doubt, but that there is no true religion, where Images are set vp and adored: Of Epiphanius, who liuing also in that age, rent Epiph. Epist. ad Ioan▪ Hieros. in pieces the image which hee found set vp in a Church, saying, It was against the Scrìpture to hang vp Images in Churches. Of which fact of his, whereas someBell. de Imag. Sanctor. ca. 9. §. ad quintum. make doubt, Cassander saith, Constat Cass Consult. ca. de Imag. pa. 167., It is certainly knowne that Epiphanius did so; and for this cause not onely Waldensis reproues him, and saith, As one Mr. Robert had done before; that Epiphanius Th. Wald. de Sacram. tit. 17. ca. 157. pa. 325. did that perhaps of zeale, but not according to knowledge: but Alphonsus Alp. à cast. lib 8. aduer. haeres. voce Imago. à Castro addes,
that Epiphaniu • though for this cause hee be not an heriticke, yet hee did erre herein, and did contrary to the Scripture. Of Pope Gregory the Great, who 600. yeares after Christ, writing to Serenus Bishop of Massilia, who had broken downe Images (which the people began then to adore,) reproues him in this mannerGreg. Epist. 9. lib. 9 Ind 4., Truely I commend you, Quod ea adorari ve • uisses, That you forbade them to adore Images, but I reprooue you for breaking them downe: That should not haue beene broken downe, Quod non ad adorandum in Ecclesiis, sed ad instruendas solummodo mentes fuit collocatum, which was there set vp onely for instruction, but not for adoration; then which no cleerer testimony can possibly bee desired. But omitting all the rest, I will heere onely propose the words of their owne Cassander, which fully demonstrate the falshood of Pope Hadrian: Certum est, It is certaine saith heCass. loc. cit. pa. 163., that in the beginning of the Gospel preached, there was no vse of Images; especially in the Churches, as by Clemens, and Arnobius is euident. And as for veneration, or adoration of them, hee further declares, Quantum Ibid. pa. 6 • . veteres initio Eccl • siae, ab omni veneratione imaginum abhorruerunt, How the ancient Church did euen abhorre the worshipping of Images; adding one thing of speciall note, Non tunc valeba • illa ratio, That excuse would not then serue the turne, which now is pretended; that they gaue not that worship to the Images themselues, but to those, who were represented by those Images: for this colour of excuse, saith he, did the Paganes also vse; as Arnobius and Lactantius declare: adding further, that such worship as is giuen to God by Images, Non satis castum &
conueni • ntem Deo esse, Is neither chaste, nor fi •• ing for God, but deuised by them that are superstitious. Thus and much more Cassander. By whose testimony, the vntruth of Pope Hadrian doth most cleerely appeare, who affi • mes Images not onely to haue been set vp in Churches, but adored also by the Church, euen from the Apostles time.

For his approuing false and forged writings, wee need to goe no further, then to the lying and legendarian Acts of Siluester, which hee Hadr. 1. Epist. 1. c • tes as Bin. not▪ in Conc. Rom. 1. sub Siluestro. authenticall; or to the first Romane C • tatur • d concilium ab Hadriano Epist, 3. ca. 53. Synod vnder Siluester, and that famous disputation betwixt the Pope and the Iewes, which we haue before demonstrated to be a famous lye. Yet let mee adde one instance more, and that is his alledgingHadr. 1. Epist. 3. ca. 34. for adoration of Images the booke of Athanasius questions to Antiochus: wherein the worshipping of Images is as cleerely taught, as in the second Nicene Synod it selfe. For thereAthan. Archepis. Alexand. quast. ad An • ochum. q. 39. it is said, That Christians doe adore Images; that they who refuse them, are, dementes, madde people: and further to shew what rare and admirable effects the adoration of Images hath wrought, it is there declared: How when a certaine Monke at Ierusalem, had beene long vexed with a, diuel, (it was daemon scortationis, as Sophronius Sophronius citatur à Concilio Nic 2. Act 4 pa. 3 • 6. Vbi haec eadē historia r • citatur ex Soph. & approbatu • à Concilio. expresseth,) The diuel at one time appeared vnto him, and said, If thou would not haue me to vexe thee any more, doe not worship this Image of the blessed Virgin, and then I will forsake thee. Quid ad haec respondebunt, what can they, who forbid adoration of Images, answere vnto these things? saith Pope Hadrians Athanasius?

What else can they, or should they answer, but
that Pope Hadrian striues to maintaine superstition and Idolatry, by lying and forged writings? That this author, cited by Pope Hadrian, as the writing of St.Nā cū Concilium Francofordense de beati Athanasij Alexandriae Episcopi, verba f • cisset, Hadrianus co • refellens ait, Eiusdē Athanasij sententias fideliter proferimus. Hadr loc. citat. Athanasius of Alexandria is such, Posseuine will tell them, Constat Posseu. in verbo Athanasius. pa. 127., it is manifest that this is not the booke of Athanasius, seeing Epiphanius and Greg. Nissene are cited therein as ancient authors; who both followed Athanasius. Bellarmine will tell them the same: The questions Athanasij esse nō possunt Bell. li. de scrip. eccl. in Athanasio. to Antiochus cannot be the booke of Athanasius. And whereas Bellarmine himselfe had sometimes alledgedBell. lib. de Notis eccl. ca. 9. §. Xenaias. & lib. 1. de Purg. ca. 6. §. Primus. this, as the booke of the ancient and holy Father Athanasius, hee afterwards retracts this his errour, and saith, I doe not thinke Bellar. Recog. in lib. 4. de Concil & eccl. ca. 9. that Athanasius Bishop of Alexandria is the author thereof.

Besides this, the sottishnesse and grosse ignorance, which the forgerer in euery page of that booke bewrayes, doth certainly demonstrate that St. Athanasius was not the author therof. Qu. 52. it is determined for an vndoubted Haud dubie lux praecedit te • ebras. truth, that at the creation light was before darknesse: quite contrary to the ScriptureGen. 1. 2. 3., and the Iewish account euer since the creation. Qu. 64. it is said, that Ionas died three seuerall times, once when Elias raised vp the widowes sonne of Sarepta; againe, when hee was in the Whales belly; and thirdly, by his naturall death after hee was deliuered out of the Whale: A fable, grounded on the Synopsis Dor. Syn. in voce Ionas. Dorothei, of which Bellarmine saithIlla Synopsis plena est fabulis. Bell. lib. de scrip. eccl. in Dorotheo., (and saith truely) that it is full of lyes. And yet this which hee sayth of Ionas, is as true, as that the EunuchVt ibidem Doroth. Pont. whom Philip baptized, and Caesar, were two of the seuentie Disciples of Christ: or that Priscilla and Iunia (two women)
werePriscilla Colophouiae Episcopus fuit, Iunia Apamiae. ibid. Bishops. Quae. 47. Hee sets downe for a certaintie that Paradise is the East of the whole earth, and further East then India: adding, that the spices which come from the East Indies, and other easterly countries, are more fragrant, because they are neere to Paradise; by the fragrancy of which, and the trees therein, the Indian fruits are made more sweete and odoriferous. A sottish conceit, not onely because there is no absolute East of the whole world; but because it is certaine, that Paradise was neere or about Mesopotamia and Babylonia, as besides the consent of the bestVid. Iuniū notis in cap. 2. Gen. Hopkins. in Synopsi Paradis • . Bened. Perer. Com. in Gen. lib. 3. q. 2. & 3. Writers, the riuers Tigris and Euphrates, which compasse Mesopotamia, and which watered the garden, doe infallibly demonstrate Quae. 54. hee saith, That Christ was conceiued on the 25. of March, because on the very same day, God at the beginning created Adam: where besides the reason, void of reason, it is vtterly vntrue, that God created the world in March, or at the vernum aequinoctium, but (as in another Treatise I haue fully prooued) about the aequinoctium hibernum. Qu. 65. hee saith that Tharshis, to which Ionas fled, was a citie of India; a verie fable. Witnesse Iosephus, who saithIosep. lib. 9 Antiq. ca. 11. & Iosephū ita sensisse ait Hieron, in ca. 66. & ca. 2. Isaiae., Ionas taking ship at Ioppe, went to Tharshis of Cili • ia. Witnesse St. Ierome: whose opinionSensit per Tharsū, mare significa • i. Hier. in ca. 10. Daniel., though it bee not true therein, yet hee expresly reiectsIbidem. that of his going to India; adding, that most Vt Ple • ique 〈…〉 . Writers doe take Tharshis of Cilicia to bee there meant. The text it selfe puts this matter out of doubt: where it is saidIona. 1. 3. ▪ that Ionas went to Iapho, and there found a ship going to Tharshis: And that Iapho is the same
with Ioppe, not onely Adricomius Ad • ic. in Theat. terrae Sanctae. in Tribu Dan. nu. 29., Ortelius Ortet. Synon. in Ioppe., and other Geographers witnesse; but the very Italian name of Ioppe, which to this day is called Iapho Ortet ibid., doth demonstrate. Now Ioppe is a Maritime towne, on the West side of Iury, situated on the mare Mediterraneum, or as some call it, Syriacum; whence there is a straight passage through the Mediterraneā Sea to Tharsus of Cilicia, but notNeque en • m Ionas de Ioppe nauigans, ad Indiā poterat peruenire, ad quam illo mari non potest nauigari Hier. com. in ca. 2, Isai. to the Indies.
